section.hand:
To S
r
Francis Walsingham N
o
12. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 12 Novem
b
To M
r
Secretary
It may please yo
r
H. at
e earnest shute of some spetiall
sons heere I write unto yo
w
3 dayes past in
e favo
r
of a
duch Capt
n
who was also
e bearer of my lett
rs
, requesting
yo
r
H. that yf for such services as he p
r
tended to have don for
hir
Ma
ty
any ord
r
shalbe
hath bin given for his recompense he
may by yo
r
favourable meanes be assisted to receave yt.
the same
ty hath also sollicited
Barnevelt
e Advisall of
Holland,
& others to recommend his request to
Ortels
furderance
w
ch
they have don very earnestly. w
th
all they have signified
in secret to
e Capt
n
both by word & by writing, as hee him self
hath p
r
mised me to declare unto yo
w
, & I have adv
r
tized in my
form
r
letter,
t
yf hir Ma
ty
hath passed any graunt of
recompense unto him, yt is detayned from him, & receaved
by some other, & that his request wilbe rejected & tourned
ov
r
to
e
States of Holland
, w
th
out
e privity of hir Ma
ty
this is
e malitious conceat of
e man, & those of his faction
w
ch
I have alwaies bin
suaded notw
th
standing all
e good
meanes
t
can bee used, will nev
r
alter untill her Ma
ty
shall eith
r
yeeld to follow his humo
r
in all thing
or seek
some meanes
to cutt him of fr
o
e government. It may please yo
r
H. to
ob
s
ve w
th
all
e disposition of
t
Capt
n
who is contented to
betray his friend
at
e very same instant as they do their
uttermost endevour to stand him in steed. for mine owne
te
I have no oth
r
notion of his qualities, but I see by his dealing
hee may be made to
s
ve to as many good purposes as
any oth
r
bad instrument. The Sconse of
Rees
w
ch
I
signified in my last was besieged by
ennemy, is sithens
taken, w
th
all
e artellery & oth
r
provision
t
was in yt
but
e souldiers
mitted to de
te, who neither fought nor
attended any shot. the Muteny in
[Zgravenwert]
will not be
[appreased] w
th
2500
[ls]
[st
rs
] w
ch
hath bin offred unto them, the
demand doth encrease ev
r
y daie, and doth not amount to so
litell as 10000
[ls]
, w
ch
is not heer to be had. These five daies
the Deputies
t
came last out of
England
have continued their
reporte to
e
general States
of theyr negotiation there, w
ch
when
they have finished I will call earnestly up
o
th
e
to
fourme
theyr promise to yo
r
Ho. in
e cause of
Vasseur
wherof I have
put
em already in remembrance & they have
mised to do theyr
best. Letters written hether fr
o
Collen
advertize
t
there are
in a redines to m
r
che toward
e ayde of
e
Frenche K
7000 horse
& 50 ensignes of footemen whose rendyvous is assigned the
20 of
is moneth at
Oppenheim
by
ments.
Yt is held for
c
r
tayne
t
e Spaniard
to
e nomb
r
of 1500 ar mutined in
Dermon[d]
& comit many outrages over all those quarters. Yt is in delib
r
a
o
n
among us at
is p
nt
wheth
r
considering the dang
r
of
Gelderland
by
e meanes of
e Ennemies retorne, yt may be expedient
t
all
e forces
of these contreyes both English & oth
r
be sent thether, wherupon ther
is nothing yet resolved. There is also a p
nt
consulta
o
n about
e surprising
of
e Ennemies fort before
Zutphen,
w
ch
is thought will prove an easy enterprise and
fol.178v
very profitable to
e countrey. The state heer ys very much troubled
by reason of a new mutiny raysed in theyr garrison of
Wike
a place of strength & of great importance about 2 leagues
from
Utrecht,
where
e souldiers require to be discharged of their
obedience, & demand their full count & [.], In effect
all theyr gov
r
ment heer ys so voyde of yt ap
tayneth to good
gov
r
ment, so confuse, so partiall, so full of injustice, as almost
all men wax wery of doing
s
vice to
e countrey, for theyr ys
no gove
r
no
r
to take notice of any mans v
r
tu or vices wh
r
by the
good may stand in hope of reward, or
e badd in feare of
punishment, in w
ch
respect & for
e hard measure, w
ch
they daily
offer to theyr martiall men, yt is greatly feared
t
as they
have lately begun in
Sgravenwert,
Lifkens Hoeke
,
Lillo
& Wijke, so there wilbe ere bee long in gen
r
all revolte in most of theyr garrisons.
